facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated April 20, 1967 of Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision No. 502 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 14 of 1968. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 20, 1967 of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision No. 502 of 1966.

facts.text: Investigation of offences under ss. 420, 467, 471 and 120B IPC.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrse of investigation of offences under ss. 420, 467, 471 and 120 B.I.P. Code the Officer in charge of the investigation submitted an application before the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta,

facts.text: Jugal Kishore More believed to be in Hong Kong.

anchor.surface_text: for an order that a warrant for the arrest of Jugal Kishore More and certain other named persons be issued and that the warrant be, forwarded with the relevant records and evidence to the Ministry of External Affairs, Government of India, for securing extradition of More who was then believed to be in Hong Kong.

facts.text: Criminal conspiracy in Calcutta between May 1961 and December 1962 to defraud Government of India in respect of India's foreign exchange.

anchor.surface_text: It was stated in the application that More and others were parties to a criminal companyspiracy in Calcutta between May 1961 and December 1962 to defraud the Government of India in respect of Indias foreign exchange, and their presence was required for trial.

facts.text: Chief Presidency Magistrate held enquiry and on July 19, 1965 ordered prima facie case of criminal conspiracy hatched in Calcutta, More one of conspirators.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Presidency Magistrate held an enquiry and recorded an order on July 19, 1965, that on the materials placed before him, a prima facie case was made out of a criminal companyspiracy, 32 3 was hatched in Calcutta within his jurisdiction, and More was one of the companyspirators.

facts.text: Chief Presidency Magistrate directed issuance of non-bailable warrant for arrest of More on July 19, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: He accordingly directed that a numberbailable warrant in Form 11 Sch. V of the Code of Criminal Procedure be issued for the arrest of More, and that the warrant be sent to the Secretary Home  Political  Department, Government of West Bengal,

facts.text: Warrant sent to Secretary Home Political Department, Government of West Bengal with request to ensure execution.

anchor.surface_text: with a request to take all necessary steps to ensure execution of the warrant. A companyy of the warrant was sent to the Commissioner of Police, Calcutta, for information.

facts.text: More described in warrant as Manager, Premko Traders of 7, Wyndhan Street and 28, Kings Road, Hong Kong.

anchor.surface_text: In the warrant More was described as Manager, Premko Traders of 7, Wyndhan Street and 28, Kings Road, Hong Kong. The Chief Presidency Magistrate forwarded to the Government of West Bengal,

facts.text: Warrant forwarded per procedure in Government of India, Ministry of External Affairs letter No. K/52/6131/41 dated 21st May, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: the warrant with attested companyies of the evidence recorded at the enquiry and photostat companyies of documents tendered by the prosecution in evidence in accordance with the procedure laid down in Government of India, Ministry of External Affairs, letter No. K/52/ 6131/41 dated 21st May, 1955.

facts.text: Warrant forwarded by West Bengal Govt to Ministry of External Affairs, Govt of India.

anchor.surface_text: The warrant was forwarded by the Government of West Bengal to the Ministry of External Affairs, Government of India.

facts.text: MEA forwarded warrant to High Commissioner for India, Hong Kong, who requested Colonial Secretary, Hong Kong for extradition under Fugitive Offenders Act, 1881.

anchor.surface_text: The Ministry of External Affairs forwarded the warrant to the High Commissioner for India, Hong Kong, who in his turn, requested the Colonial Secretary, Hong Kong, for an order extraditing More under the Fugitive Offenders Act, 1881,  44 and 45 Vict., c. 69 , to India for trial for offences described in the warrant.

facts.text: Central Magistrate, Hong Kong endorsed the warrant and directed arrest under Fugitive Offenders Act, 1881.

anchor.surface_text: The Central Magistrate, Hong Kong, endorsed the warrant and directed the Hong Kong Police, pursuant to section 13 of Part 11 and section 26 of Part IV of the Fugitive Offenders Act, 1881, to arrest More.

facts.text: More arrested on November 24, 1965 in Hong Kong.

anchor.surface_text: More was arrested on November 24, 1965.

facts.text: Central Magistrate Hong Kong overruled objection on jurisdiction on April 4, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: By order dated April 4, 1966, the Central Magistrate, Hong Kong, over-ruled the objection raised on behalf of More that the Court had numberjurisdiction to proceed in the matter under the Fugitive Offenders Act, 1881, since the Republic of India was numberlonger a British Possession.

facts.text: Hanuman Prasad, father of More, moved petition in Calcutta High Court on May 16, 1966 under s.439 CrPC and Art.227 Constitution to quash warrant and proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: On May 16, 1966, Hanuman Prasad-father of More moved in the High Court of Calcutta a petition under S. 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and Art. 227 of the Constitution for an order quashing the warrant of arrest issued against More and all proceedings taken pursuant thereto

facts.text: Calcutta High Court Division Bench: A. Roy J held warrant not illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was heard before a Division Bench of the High Court. A. Roy, J., held that the warrant issued by the Chief Presidency Magistrate was number illegal and the procedure followed for securing extradition of More was number irregular.

facts.text: Gupta J held warrant without jurisdiction, no notified order under Extradition Act 1962.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of Gupta, J., the warrant issued by the Chief Presidency Magistrate and the steps taken pursuant to the warrant were without jurisdiction, that the request made to the Hong Kong Government by the Government of India was also without authority in the absence of a numberified order under S. 3 of the Extradition Act, 1962,

facts.text: R. Mukherji J quashed warrant dated July 30, 1965 and all subsequent proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge accordingly ordered that the warrant of arrest dated July 30, 1965, issued by the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta, against More and all subsequent proceedings taken by the Chief Presidency Magistrate and the other respondents be quashed.

facts.text: State of West Bengal appealed to Supreme Court with special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The State of West Bengal has appealed to this Court with special leave.

facts.text: Supreme Court notification dated May 21, 1955 by MEA on procedure for extradition from Commonwealth countries.

anchor.surface_text: After this judgment was delivered, the Government of India, Ministry of External Affairs, issued a numberification on May 21, 1955, to all State Governments of Part A, B, C D States.

facts.text: Extradition Act 34 of 1962 enacted, but no notification including Hong Kong.

anchor.surface_text: But in the Schedule to the Act Hong Kong is number specified as one of the companymonwealth companyntry and numbernotification ,has been issued by the Government of India under S. 2 a  adding to the First Schedule Hong Kong as a companymonwealth companyntry.

facts.text: Chief Presidency Magistrate issued warrant pursuant to 1955 notification.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Presidency Magistrate Calcutta made out the warrant for the arrest of More pursuant to that numberification and sent the warrant to the Secretary, Home  Political  Department, Government of West Bengal.

facts.text: Supreme Court held procedure followed was not illegal.

anchor.surface_text: Issue of the warrant and the procedure followed in transmitting the warrant were number illegal, number even irregular.

facts.text: Appeal allowed, High Court order set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal must therefore be allowed and the order passed by the High Court set aside.

issues.text: Whether the Chief Presidency Magistrate had power to issue the warrant of arrest against More who was outside India and forward it through government channels for extradition pursuant to the 1955 MEA notification.
Whether the warrant issued by the Chief Presidency Magistrate had extra-territorial operation enforceable in Hong Kong.
Whether the procedure followed by the Chief Presidency Magistrate in issuing the warrant and sending it to the Home Department complied with the Code of Criminal Procedure and was legal.

anchor.surface_text: He accordingly directed that a non-bailable warrant in Form 11 Sch. V of the Code of Criminal Procedure be issued for the arrest of More, and that the warrant be sent to the Secretary Home Political Department, Government of West Bengal, with a request to take all necessary steps to ensure execution of the warrant.

issues.text: Whether a notified order under Section 3 of the Extradition Act, 1962 was required for requisition to Hong Kong, and absence thereof rendered the proceedings without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of Gupta, J., the warrant issued by the Chief Presidency Magistrate and the steps taken pursuant to the warrant were without jurisdiction, that the request made to the Hong Kong Government by the Government of India was also without authority in the absence of a notified order under S. 3 of the Extradition Act, 1962,

issues.text: Whether the Fugitive Offenders Act, 1881 had ceased to be part of the law of India after the coming into force of the Constitution and could not be resorted to for extradition.

anchor.surface_text: The Ministry of External Affairs forwarded the warrant to the High Commissioner for India, Hong Kong, who in his turn, requested the Colonial Secretary, Hong Kong, for an order extraditing More under the Fugitive Offenders Act, 1881, 44 and 45 Vict., c. 69 , to India for trial for offences described in the warrant.

issues.text: Whether the irregularity or illegality in the procedure for securing extradition or arrest affects the jurisdiction of Indian courts to try the accused once brought to India.

anchor.surface_text: Where a man is in the country and is charged before a Magistrate with an offence under the Penal Code it will not avail him to say that he was brought there illegally from a foreign country.

issues.text: Whether the 1955 MEA notification prescribing procedure for extradition from Commonwealth countries invaded the authority of the courts or was merely advisory.

anchor.surface_text: But Gupta, J., and Mukherjee, J., thought that the notification issued by the Government of India setting out the procedure to be followed by a Magistrate, where the offender is not in Indian territory and his extradition is to be secured, amounted to an invasion on the authority of the Courts.

issues.text: Whether the requisition by Government of India to Hong Kong was barred by the Extradition Act, 1962 in the absence of notification including Hong Kong.

arguments.claim: The Court had no jurisdiction to proceed under the Fugitive Offenders Act, 1881, since the Republic of India was no longer a British Possession.

arguments.court_reasoning: Issue of warrant and procedure not illegal nor irregular.

arguments.claim: Extradition is surrender by one state to another; political act by executive pursuant to treaty; courts ensure prima facie case.

anchor.surface_text: Extradition is the surrender by one State to another of a person desired to be dealt with for crimes of which he has been accused or convicted and which are justiciable in the courts of the other State.

arguments.claim: Requisition for surrender is function of state, not courts; warrant has no extra-territorial operation inherently.

anchor.surface_text: Requisition for surrender is not the function of the Courts but of the State. A warrant issued by a Court for an offence committed in a country from its very nature has no extra-territorial operation.

arguments.claim: Mode of bringing accused to India does not affect jurisdiction to try if offence committed in India (Savarkar principle).

anchor.surface_text: Where a man is in the country and is charged before a Magistrate with an offence under the Penal Code it will not avail him to say that he was brought there illegally from a foreign country.

arguments.claim: 1955 MEA notification is advisory procedure for securing executive assistance, not invasion of judicial authority.

anchor.surface_text: After this judgment was delivered, the Government of India, Ministry of External Affairs, issued a notification on May 21, 1955, to all State Governments of Part A, B, C D States.

holdings.text: Issue of the warrant and the procedure followed in transmitting the warrant were not illegal, not even irregular.

anchor.surface_text: Issue of the warrant and the procedure followed in transmitting the warrant were not illegal, not even irregular. One more argument remains to be noticed. It is true that under the Extradition Act 34 of 1962 no notification has been issued including Hong Kong in the list of the Commonwealth countries from which extradition of fugitives from justice may be secured.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Magistrate had prima facie case; followed advisory 1955 MEA notification for executive assistance; no statutory bar.

holdings.text: The notification issued by the Government of India was only in the nature of advice about the procedure to be followed and did not in any manner seek to impose any executive will upon the Courts in matters judicial.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Presidency Magistrate Calcutta made out the warrant for the arrest of More pursuant to that notification and sent the warrant to the Secretary, Home Political Department, Government of West Bengal. Validity of the steps taken in accordance with the notification by the Chief Presidency Magistrate is questioned in this appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification provides procedure for executive aid in extradition; post-Menon judgment to resolve practical issues without repealing old acts; not binding on courts.

holdings.text: There was no illegality committed by the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta, in sending the warrant to the Secretary, Home Political Department, Government of West Bengal, for transmission to the Government of India, Ministry of External Affairs, for taking further steps for securing the presence of More in India to undergo trial.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Warrant valid under CrPC Sch V Form II; s.82 allows execution anywhere in India; seeks executive diplomatic assistance.

holdings.text: We are unable to agree with the High Court that because of the enactment of the Extradition Act 34 of 1962 the Government of India is prohibited from securing through diplomatic channels the extradition of an offender for trial of an offence committed within India.
holdings.reasoning_summary: 1962 Act consolidates but does not bar diplomatic requisitions absent notification; Hong Kong not scheduled.

holdings.text: On the principle of Vinayak Damodar Savarkar's case the contention about the invalidity of the arrest cannot affect the jurisdiction of the Courts in India to try More if and when he is brought here.

anchor.surface_text: Where a man is in the country and is charged before a Magistrate with an offence under the Penal Code it will not avail him to say that he was brought there illegally from a foreign country.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Savarkar precedent: mode of bringing accused irrelevant if offence committed in India and accused present.

holdings.text: A warrant issued by a Court for an offence committed in a country from its very nature has no extra-territorial operation.

anchor.surface_text: Requisition for surrender is not the function of the Courts but of the State. A warrant issued by a Court for an offence committed in a country from its very nature has no extra-territorial operation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Warrant is domestic command; extra-territorial effect via state requisition and foreign endorsement per treaty/municipal law.

holdings.text: This Court has no authority to sit in judgment over the order passed by the Hong Kong Central Magistrate.
holdings.reasoning_summary: HK acted per own municipal law (Fugitive Offenders Act); no jurisdiction to review foreign court.

holdings.text: Whether having regard to the political status of India since January 26, 1950, the Fugitive Offenders Act, 1881, insofar as it purported to treat India as a British Possession imposed an obligation to deliver offenders in pursuance of the India Consequential Provision Act 1949 is a question on which it is not necessary to express an opinion.

anchor.surface_text: But in the Schedule to the Act Hong Kong is not specified as one of the commonwealth country and no notification has been issued by the Government of India under S. 2(a) adding to the First Schedule Hong Kong as a commonwealth country.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not decided as unnecessary; Act repealed by 1962; distinguished Menon as reverse case.

holdings.text: The appeal must therefore be allowed and the order passed by the High Court set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal must therefore be allowed and the order passed by the High Court set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative holdings reverse HC quashing of warrant and proceedings.

India Consequential Provisions Act 1949 ensures continuity of UK laws post-republic, supporting the holding by enabling narrower constitutional interpretation of Fugitive Offenders Act 1881 that accommodates India's changed political status without treating it as British possession.

The Act's provision for continuity of UK laws post-1949 directly addresses the issue of whether Fugitive Offenders Act 1881 ceased post-Constitution by supporting ongoing application through reading down.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal must therefore be allowed and the order passed by the High Court set aside.

The Chief Presidency Magistrate Calcutta made out the warrant for the arrest of More pursuant to that notification and sent the warrant to the Secretary, Home Political Department, Government of West Bengal. Validity of the steps taken in accordance with the notification by the Chief Presidency Magistrate is questioned in this appeal.
The appeal must therefore be allowed and the order passed by the High Court set aside.

edges.explanation: h3 finds no illegality in sending the warrant via Home Department, supporting the procedural concept in c6 for extradition warrants

anchor.surface_text: Requisition for surrender is not the function of the Courts but of the State. A warrant issued by a Court for an offence committed in a country from its very nature has no extra-territorial operation.
